# Ako Edward Oben

Ako Edward Oben is a Cameroonian academic professor and administrator. He has held several key positions in higher education, including serving as the rector of the University of Maroua until 2017.
Early life
Oben was born on May 18, 1951, in Ossing village, Eyumojock Subdivision, Manyu Division, Cameroon.
Education
His early education began at Basel Mission Primary School in Ossing, where he obtained his First School Leaving Certificate in 1963. He then attended Bilingual Grammar School, Man O’War Bay, earning his General Certificate of Education (GCE) Ordinary Level in 1969. His academic excellence continued at The Cameroon College of Arts, Science and Technology, Bambili, where he obtained his GCE Advanced Level in 1971. For higher education, he pursued a Bilingual degree in English and French at the University of Yaoundé, graduating with a BA (Hons) in 1975. Seeking further academic challenges, he moved to the United States in 1976, earning a Master’s degree in Afro-American Studies from Atlanta University, Georgia, in 1978. His studies focused on African American, Afro-French, and Caribbean Literatures.
Driven by his passion for literature and cultural studies, he obtained a PhD in Comparative Literature from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, in 1982. During his doctoral research, he worked with renowned scholars such as Professors Owen Aldridge, François Jost, and Richard Barksdale.
Career
Oben has made significant contributions to education in Cameroon and beyond.
* University leadership: he served as rector of the University of Maroua from 2008 to 2017, overseeing academic and administrative development.
* Higher education policy: as vice rector at the University of Yaoundé I, he played a crucial role in research and cooperation, strengthening national and international academic ties.
* Academic governance: he was a technical adviser at the Presidency of the Republic of Cameroon, coordinating cultural and social affairs across multiple ministerial departments.
* International influence: he was elected First Vice President of the Association of African Universities, helping shape higher education policies across Africa.
* Mentorship and research: he has supervised over 20 PhD students and more than 40 Master's degree candidates, contributing to the academic growth of many scholars.
Publications
Notable works include:
* "Migration, Culture, and Transnational Identities: Critical Essays" – a scholarly exploration of migration and identity in a globalized world.
* "American Literature: Periods, Trends, and Themes" – co-authored with Sarah Anyang Agbor and Manyaka Toko Djockoua, this book examines key developments in American literary history/
